#Text=Become Computer Literate
#Text=Are you the kind of parent who has absolutely no idea how to use a computer ?
#Text=Someone who has never touched a computer before and just got here by luck ?
#Text=This article will help you become computer literate .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Find a real person to help you ; not just someone online .
#Text=Some good people to ask are your own kids .
#Text=They know a lot about the computer , but they may be annoyed if you ask too much .
#Text=Also , check out some books at the library about computers .
#Text=There are a couple of good books out there .
#Text=Learn the basic steps to get on the computer .
#Text=Learn how to turn the computer on , off , on standby if applicable , how to log off if using Windows XP , and how to put discs in the disc drive .
#Text=Learn about the assorted programs and applications that you will be using .
#Text=Install them on the computer by placing the CD into the disc drive , and following the installation wizard that pops up on the screen .
#Text=After installing , play around with the application .
#Text=this will help you understand the program better .
#Text=Learn a little about some of the chat jargon or chatspeak .
#Text=Some examples are " lol " ( laugh out loud ) , and " btw " ( by the way ) .
#Text=Also pay attention to - 1337 speak , which means " leet " or " elite " .

column1: #Text=You wo n't really need to worry about Elite speak , as it was mainly used by hackers and crackers in the 1990s .
#Text=Now it is mainly used by " wannabe " hackers , so you are most likely safe .
#Text=Check out the external links for more information .
#Text=Also , remember that this will help you figure out what your children are saying online when they send you IMs , or instant messages .

#Text=Set up an email account , which will be required to register with just about any website that allows posting messages ( ie : forums , blogs , and sites with built-in chat rooms or IRC clients ) .
#Text=Find a free email provider you like such as Google , Yahoo , Hotmail , or AOL .
#Text=Sign up using their instructions .
#Text=Learn a little about bad people online .
#Text=First , there are pedophiles which are a danger to your kids .
#Text=There are also scams , viruses , cookie grabbers , and Trojan horses .
#Text=See external links for more info .
#Text=Also , always keep your computer up to date with security patches and other updates .
#Text=Learn to recognize spam and forged emails some of which can look very real .
#Text=Learn about money mule scams so that you do not fall for them .
#Text=Learn to protect your computer by installing anti-spy and anti-virus software .
#Text=Explore a little on the web .
#Text=Visit Google.com to search for sites that focus on some of your interests .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Some public institutions , like libraries or schools , offer free computer courses for people of all ages .
#Text=If possible , you ought to invest some time into such programs .
#Text=Before making choices , learn about the advantages and disadvantages of the program .
#Text=Some libraries have computer courses that you can take to learn .
#Text=Make sure the books you look at are up to date .
#Text=Make sure your computer is good for your use .
#Text=If you want to just use it for taxes and email , performance is less useful but if you want to do 3D art , you need a a more beefed up computer .
#Text=On many programs such as Wordpad , there will be a button in the upper part of your screen that says " Help " .
#Text=This is a useful and quick access way to get answers .
#Text=Remember , do n't download anything if you are not sure about it .
#Text=Get enough hard drive space !
#Text=This is basically how much room your computer has for files .
#Text=50 GB should be sufficient .
#Text=Some applications can help simplify things .
#Text=Most libraries will have computers in them .
#Text=Consider going there , as they are free .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do not pay for help unless you have no other alternative .
#Text=Be careful about opening attachments in emails , especially from people you do n't know , since the attachment may give you a virus .
#Text=Do not be fooled by unrealistic claims .
#Text=A good rule of thumb is " if it sounds too good to be true , it usually is ! " .
#Text=And do not put your mobile or home phone number anywhere unless you have read and understood ALL the terms and conditions .
#Text=Who knows , once claimed a free ringtone , now a broken cell .
#Text=If you download files , make sure to run a virus check on it before you open it .
#Text=It may contain a virus or other mal-ware that can pose a threat to your system .
#Text=Dangerous emails can also come from your friends .
#Text=If they have opened and/or received an email with an attachment , it may hijack their address book and send the program to everyone in it .
#Text=Remember , when it comes to viruses , if you are n't part of the solution , you are part of the problem .
#Text=Stay protected .
#Text=Do not overestimate how good your computer is or how much room because your computer could overload .
#Text=Things
#Text=You 'll Need
#Text=A computer and Internet connection ( personal or public )
#Text=A helpful person or other resource
